The range of genetic/environmental interactions over the course of
human development affecting cognitive, emotional and behavioral
function is virtually limitless. As a result, it is impossible to capture
the full range of psychopathology in the categorical diagnostic cate-
gories that we are now using. Hence, it is also necessary to include
“other specified/unspecified” disorder options for presentations that
do not fit exactly into the diagnostic boundaries of disorders in each
chapter. In an emergency department setting, it may be possible to
identify only the most prominent symptom expressions associated
with a particular chapter—for example, delusions, hallucinations, ma-
nia, depression, anxiety, substance intoxication, or neurocognitive
symptoms—so that an “unspecified” disorder in that category is iden-
tified until a fuller differential diagnosis is possible.
